journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Differences in Knee Joint Stabilization Between Children and Adults and Between the Sexes

article-meta.aff: †Division of Physiotherapy, Department of Medical and Health Sciences, Linköping University, Linköping, Sweden
‡Rehabilitation Sciences and Physiotherapy, Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium
§Aspetar, Qatar Orthopaedic and Sports Medicine Hospital, Doha, Qatar
Investigation performed at Rehabilitation Sciences and Physiotherapy, Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium

author-notes.corresp: *Sofi Tagesson, RPT, PhD, Linköping University, Department of Medical and Health Sciences, Division of Physiotherapy, S-58183 Linköping, Sweden (e-mail: sofi.tagesson@liu.se).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Differences in knee joint stabilization between children and adults and between the sexes are not fully understood.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: To compare the knee laxity and the dynamic tibial translation between (1) children and adults, (2) girls and boys, and (3) women and men.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Controlled laboratory study.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Sixty-seven children (aged 8-13 years) and 63 adults (aged 18-30 years) without previous knee injuries participated. Sagittal tibial translation was measured during the instrumented Lachman test at 90 N and 134 N (knee laxity) and during gait (dynamic translation). Tibial translation was recorded with an electrogoniometer.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Knee laxity was greater in children than in adults (Lachman test at 90 N: 9.1 ± 2.9 vs 7.3 ± 2.7, respectively; P < .001). In contrast, dynamic tibial translation during gait did not differ between children and adults. Girls and boys did not differ in knee laxity or maximum anterior tibial translation during gait, and men and women did not differ in knee laxity. Women had greater dynamic tibial translation during gait than men (7.8 ± 2.7 vs 5.7 ± 3.0, respectively; P = .004).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Children had greater knee laxity than adults, whereas the dynamic tibial translation did not differ. In adults, knee laxity did not differ between the sexes, but dynamic tibial translation was greater in women.

sec.title: Clinical Relevance:
sec.p: Children and men had less dynamic tibial translation during gait in proportion to their maximum knee laxity. The observed less dynamic tibial translation in children and adult men might be related to their reduced risk of sustaining an anterior cruciate ligament injury.

body.p: Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injuries are less common in children than in adults3,26; however, the incidence of ACL injuries in children and adolescents is increasing.19 The lower ACL injury rate in children has been ascribed to the relative strength of the ligaments versus the physes in skeletally immature persons. Although ACL injuries in adults and adolescents predominantly are intrasubstance tears, many ACL injuries in children involve tibial avulsion fractures.3,9,29,35 The ACL in children consists of collagen fibers that are continuous with the perichondrium of the tibial epiphyseal cartilage, and this structure may protect against a ligament rupture.9,29 The risk for complete ACL tears increases as children mature.35,45 Possible differences in knee joint stabilization between children and adults might also be important for the risk of sustaining an ACL injury. Knee laxity in children and adolescents decreases with age and maturation,6,12,13,18,39 and the decrease is greater in boys.1,12 A greater understanding of possible differences in knee joint stabilization between children and adults is important for preventing knee injuries in children.

In addition, the ACL injury rate is higher among women compared with men.4,32,49 Female ACLs, compared with male ACLs, likely rupture under smaller load applications.30 Studies comparing knee laxity between sexes have yielded conflicting results. Several reports presenting knee laxity in children have identified equal tibial translations in girls and boys.1,6,12,13 In contrast, Hinton et al18 reported greater knee laxity in girls compared with boys, and Shultz et al39 found greater knee laxity in boys than in girls at maturation stages 1 to 4 according to the Tanner stages of maturity and no sex differences at maturation stage 5. Falciglia et al,12 however, reported a greater decrease in knee laxity from Tanner stages 2 to 4 in boys compared with girls.

Among adults, women are reported to have greater knee laxity than men.7,34,36,37,46 One study showed greater knee laxity in women in the manual maximum drawer test but no sex differences in the passive or active drawer test performed with the KT-1000 arthrometer.27 Another study reported greater anterior knee laxity in women compared with men but no sex differences in posterior knee laxity.43 Huston and Wojtys21 identified greater knee laxity in women compared with men in an athletic group but no sex differences in a group of active volunteers. Furthermore, knee laxity varies across the menstrual cycle, with women having cycle-specific greater laxity compared with men.41,42

Increased knee laxity is a suggested risk factor for ACL injury.31,46 Earlier studies evaluating knee stability in children have measured only knee laxity, that is, static tibial translation, which is the measured translation when anterior and posterior forces are applied to the proximal tibia.6,12,13,39 Most studies comparing knee stability between sexes also have measured only knee laxity,‖ even though it does not correlate with knee function.10,20,33,44 Dynamic knee stability is the ability of the knee joint to remain stable during the rapidly changing loads that occur during activity50 and can be evaluated using, for example, a goniometer chain such as the CA-4000 (OSI Inc, Hayward, California),22,23 an optoelectronic motion analysis system,16 or dynamic magnetic resonance imaging.5 Dynamic knee stability is probably more important than laxity for knee-related functional outcome.22 Furthermore, knowledge of dynamic knee stability may provide additional information that helps to predict the risk of ACL injury and to explain the differences in ACL injury rates between different groups of people. It is possible that dynamic knee stability could be addressed in future preventive strategies.

The purpose of the present study was to compare knee laxity and dynamic tibial translation between (1) children and adults, (2) girls and boys, and (3) women and men. The total sagittal tibial translation during the instrumented Lachman test was measured to report the knee laxity. The maximum anterior tibial translation during gait was measured to report the dynamic tibial translation.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Skeletally immature (aged 8-13 years) and adult (aged 18-30 years) volunteers without previous knee injuries were recruited for inclusion. The majority of the children were recruited from local sport clubs, and the majority of the adults were recruited among students and employees at Ghent University, Belgium. A total of 67 children and 63 adults participated (Table 1). The project was approved by the local ethics committee (Dnr B67020097667).

sec.title: Assessment, Data Acquisition, and Analysis
sec.p: The nondominant leg was tested; leg dominance was defined as the preferred leg used to kick a ball. The testing was performed with the participants barefoot, and 1 examiner (S.T.) performed all of the testing. Sagittal tibial translation was measured during the instrumented Lachman test (anterior-posterior knee laxity) and during gait (dynamic translation).

The computerized goniometer linkage, CA-4000, was used to measure the knee flexion angle and sagittal tibial translation (Figure 1). The goniometer has been described previously.25 The CA-4000 was zeroed at the beginning of each assessment, with the participant lying supine on the examination table and the knee relaxed to full extension. To identify the reference position at each flexion angle for the calculation of tibial translation during activity, the examiner performed a passive knee extension with the patient sitting on an examination table in a position of 70° of hip flexion. With the patient relaxed, the examiner first flexed the knee to more than 100° and then extended it into hyperextension. Dynamic anterior tibial translation was calculated by subtracting the tibial position recorded at each flexion angle during the passive extension from the tibial position recorded at the same flexion angle during gait.25 For the Lachman test, the total anterior-posterior translation in the sagittal plane was recorded. Data were sampled from the potentiometers by a computer at a rate of 1000 Hz.

caption.p: The CA-4000 electrogoniometer mounted on a participant. a, Potentiometer that registers knee extension and flexion. b, Potentiometer that registers sagittal plane motion.

sec.p: The instrumented Lachman test was performed with the participant strapped to a special seat with the knee flexed to 20° to 30°. Tibial translation was recorded with the CA-4000 electrogoniometer. A force handle was used to push the proximal tibia posterior and pull anterior with a controlled force. The total anterior-posterior translations in the sagittal plane were assessed at 90 N and 134 N. The mean value of 3 repetitions was used for analysis.

During gait testing, the patients were instructed to walk as normally as possible at a self-chosen speed. Data from foot sensors were used to identify the stance phase of the gait. Maximal anterior translation during the stance phase was measured with the CA-4000 electrogoniometer (Figure 2). The mean value of 3 repetitions was used for analysis.

caption.p: Gait testing with the CA-4000 electrogoniometer.

sec.p: The measurement system has satisfactory reproducibility: The mean variation among 3 consecutive dynamic measurements (gait) was 0.03 ± 0.5 mm.24 The mean variation throughout a range of motion (a squat on 2 legs that went from 0° to 90° and back to 0°) on 2 different days was 0.73 ± 0.41 mm.25 The CA-4000 also has satisfactory validity throughout a range of motion when compared with fluoroscopy and was validated to fluoroscopy during stair ascent in 10 patients with ACL deficiency and 10 controls. The correlations between the electrogoniometric and fluoroscopic measurements (r) were >0.89 when the patella was used as the reference point and >0.94 when the femur was used as the reference point at the fluoroscopic analysis.48

sec.title: Statistical Analyses
sec.p: Sample size calculations estimated that for the Lachman test, 23 patients would be required in each group to detect a 2-mm difference in tibial translation as significant. For the gait test, 31 participants in each group would be required to detect a 2-mm difference in tibial translation as significant (α = .05, β = .20). A full factorial 2-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used on tibial translation during the Lachman test at 90 N and gait, with sex and maturity (child/adult) as factors. Bonferroni-adjusted post hoc tests were used for all pairwise comparisons between and within factors. Because of missing data, statistical calculations were not performed on tibial translation during the Lachman test at 134 N. Significance was set at P < .05 for all variables. The Pearson correlation coefficient was used for the calculation of correlations between knee laxity and dynamic tibial translation. Analyses were performed using IBM SPSS Statistics version 18-20 (SPSS Inc, Chicago, Illinois).

sec.title: Comparisons Between Children and Adults
sec.p: The knee laxity was greater in children than in adults. Maximum anterior tibial translation during gait did not differ between the 2 groups (Table 2). In the children, there was no correlation between knee laxity and maximum anterior tibial translation during gait (r = 0.231, P = .069). In the adults, there was a weak correlation between knee laxity and dynamic tibial translation (r = 0.348, P = .006). There were technical problems with the data signal from the CA-4000 and the force handle during the data collection, which led to missing data from the measurements for some participants, precluding calculation of their tibial translation during the Lachman test at 134 N (Table 2).

caption.p: Total Tibial Translation (in mm) in the Sagittal Plane During the Lachman Test and Maximum Anterior Tibial Translation During Gait in Children and Adults and in Girls, Boys, Women, and Mena

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean ± SD (n). Because of missing data, tibial translation during the Lachman test at 134 N could only be analyzed on some of the participants, and statistical calculations of this variable were therefore not performed.

sec.title: Sex Differences
sec.p: In the children’s group, girls and boys did not differ in knee laxity or maximum anterior tibial translation during gait (Table 2). Men and women also did not differ in knee laxity, but the women had greater maximum anterior tibial translation during gait compared with the men (Table 2). Because of missing data, knee laxity data during the Lachman test at 134 N were available on fewer participants (Table 2).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The children and the men had less dynamic tibial translation during gait in proportion to their maximum knee laxity. The findings indicate that children and men possibly have a more favorable strategy for stabilizing their knee joints compared with women and might therefore be at lower risk for an ACL injury, although that cannot be confirmed from this study. In addition, children had greater knee laxity compared with adults. These results are in line with those of other studies that have shown a reduction in knee laxity during pubertal growth.6,12,13,18,39

In the present study, we also investigated dynamic tibial translation during gait. There is a normal degree of ligament slackness in the joint, and measurements of laxity give us the limits of the envelope of passive motion, where the joint slips depending on muscle action or external forces.8 Measures with 90-N external anterior-posterior load define the anterior-posterior limits for this specific load. By measuring both knee laxity and dynamic tibial translation, we can study the amount of the envelope of motion at 90 N, as described before, that is observed during dynamic movements.22,23 The maximum anterior tibial translation during gait did not differ between children and adults; a possible cause for this is that the children could dynamically control their greater knee laxity during gait compared with adults. Moreover, in the adult group, men and women did not differ in knee laxity, although the women had greater maximum anterior tibial translation during gait compared with the men. Thus, the men had less maximum knee laxity during gait than their female counterparts. The observed less dynamic tibial translation in children and adult men is an interesting finding that might be related to their reduced risk of sustaining an ACL injury. Lower ACL injury rates for children compared with adults3,26 and men compared with women4,32,49 are reported in the literature.

The finding of no sex differences in knee laxity in the adult group is in line with the results from a group of active volunteers who were investigated by Huston and Wojtys.21 The activity level of the participants in that group ranged from sedentary to recreational athletics, and the findings are comparable with the results for the adult group tested in the present study. Other studies have shown that women have greater knee laxity compared with men.7,34,36,37,46 The analysis of sex differences among the children showed that girls and boys had similar knee laxity and maximum anterior tibial translation during gait. Other authors have also found equal knee laxities in girls and boys.1,6,12,13 However, some studies have identified sex differences with greater knee laxity in girls18 or in boys.39 It seems that level21 and type of sport activity36 influence knee laxity, and diverse results in studies might partly be caused by these factors. Moreover, when analyzing knee laxity in immature persons, the age of the children included affects the results,1,6,12,13,18,39 and this variable differs among studies. On the contrary, leg dominance has shown not to influence the total anterior-posterior knee laxity,11,17 and therefore, the nondominant leg was chosen for assessment in the present study.

A strength of this work is that we assessed both knee laxity and dynamic knee stability. Increased knee laxity is a suggested risk factor for ACL injury,31,46 although dynamic translation should be of more interest to examine. Dynamic stability depends on the integration of articular geometry, soft tissue restraints, and the loads applied to the joint through weightbearing and muscle activation50 and relates to the ability to stabilize the knee during activity. Knee laxity does not correlate with dynamic tibial translation,23 and some patients manage to return to sports in spite of an ACL deficiency.15,28 The present study identified a weak correlation between knee laxity and dynamic tibial translation in the adult group and no correlation in the children’s group. Based on our results in children, therefore, knee laxity is not related to their ability to stabilize the knee during activity.

However, one confounding factor in the comparison of knee laxity between children and adults is the difference in mass of the legs of children versus adults. It is possible that a fixed force to the tibia results in greater displacement of the limbs with less mass. Yet, studies have reported no associations between body mass, body mass index,38,47 or lower extremity lean mass40 and anterior-posterior knee laxity. The fact that the children use less of their maximum knee laxity during activity needs to be confirmed in future studies. One potential source of error is that some children might have walked with a stiff knee because of possible discomfort of the measurement equipment on the leg. On the other hand, the smaller anterior translation in the children may be a result of a natural increase in co-contraction and not a result of the testing situation. Indeed, young children use more co-contraction during activity than mature persons.14 Analysis of muscle activation would give a better understanding of the differences in movement pattern and strategies for dynamic joint stabilization between children and adults. These issues require further investigation. Furthermore, a limitation of the present study is that only motions in the sagittal plane were observed. This implies that the analysis of knee motion pattern was somewhat simplified in that all of the 6 degrees of freedom in the joint could not be taken into account. Tibial rotations in the transverse plane would also be interesting to investigate in terms of injury prevention and injury mechanisms.2

In conclusion, knee laxity was greater in children than in adults, whereas the dynamic tibial translation did not differ. The children’s group did not differ between girls and boys in knee laxity or dynamic tibial translation, and men and women did not differ in knee laxity. The women, however, had greater dynamic tibial translation than the men. The observed less dynamic tibial translation in children and adult men might be related to their reduced risk of sustaining an ACL injury.

ack.p: The authors acknowledge Narmin Ghani Zadeh Hesar for the recruitment of volunteers and participation in data collection.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
